s.text: But the true promise of hypermedia was linking information across a global network, and that had to wait until 1992 and Tim Berners-Lee's invention of the World Wide Web.
The Web's rapid acceptance owes much to the ease with which Web pages can be created.

The bad thing about this scheme is that since every image has a public URL, anyone can use it.
The great thing about this scheme is that if you are on a slow connection to the Internet, you can tell your browser to ignore the images.

Creating links is easy because each Web page, and each image on the page, has a unique address on the Web called a URL (Universal Resource Locator).
The offending page doesn't technically copy or distribute the image in question.
